comments.commentBody:
Will this lead last?

NY Times, you just prominently placed an article about the wikileaks e-mails in which your headline implied more Hillary Clinton corruption and buried down in the story was the truth -- that there was absolutely no evidence of any pay to play and Chelsea Clinton tried to monitor what she believed was bad behavior by Foundation staff.

Once again, the NY Times reporters work very hard to do the right wing's work to convince the American people Clinton is corrupt. No evidence necessary. Just some innuendo and the NY Times headline writers and reporters highlighting innuendoes because the facts don't make a good enough story. And maybe the right wingers will like them and stop criticizing them.

If Trump wins, he can thank Amy Chozick personally for her good job to report only the innuendos while burying the real story. Just like she did when she reporting on the "corruption" that was Hillary Clinton's bout of pneumonia.

I was watching Mrs. Clinton on the TV the other night
and got to thinking of how much she reminded me of
the female teachers -- all sadly gone now -- who made valiant attempts to stuff a bit of Latin, geometry and English composition into my very lame head back more than fifty years ago.

So, here’s a shout out to Mrs. Rossi, Mrs. Pritchett, Mrs. Arnold and Dr. Grazer and all of the others whose names escape me just now who brought me to the realization that not all wisdom resides in the minds of men.

I was the guy who sat in the back of the room who sometimes got caught in your class reading Mad magazines. The one who frequently turned in book reports based on Classics Illustrated comic books.

Thanks for putting up with me and saying nice things about me to my mother and taking me as far as you could. FWIW I am still trying hard to please you, like for example, by voting for Hillary.

I'm not sure this is so true of Philadelphia but there are African-American Trump supporters who believe the black vote generally is under-polled for Trump. You see them on television political shows. Some express opinions that there may be 10% or more black support that is "hidden" from pollsters, for obvious reasons. It's anecdotal evidence, but evidence nonetheless, when they report numerous instances of African-Americans telling them privately that to admit an intention to vote for Trump carries risk to them and their families. They don't know the pollsters who call them, and therefore may not trust them with their real voting intention.

Is this whistling past the graveyard for Trumpistas? Maybe. But I guess we'll find out fairly soon.

I don't care much for this fellow Trump. But he has exposed so much about people in general, the media, about politics and the workings of our union that we owe him a huge debt of gratitude. I hope we learn.

The Times puts this on the front page because Pennsylvania has been deemed a key state by the pundits even though this election is different from all the others, making it almost impossible to determine which states are key, if any.  Because 90 of the 91 blacks surveyed supported Clinton, the Upshot tells us she may get all the black votes in black precincts  That happened for Obama, but  there's an important difference between the two.  See if you can figure out what it is..  The Times wants you to read this and to say yahoo.  The first 20 comments all say yahoo.  This reminds me of 1984.  The Times tells their readers what to say, and they say it.  There's a lot of polling stuff that can be questioned if you don't believe everything you hear.  But that requires readers who think for themselves. I'm a card-carrying Democrat but I have found all kinds of errors and misrepresentations in the media during this campaign.  I mean today the Times is announcing a revolution among Trump followers.  That article belongs in the trash.  You can support Clinton and still criticize all the garbage the media has been spouting.  An informed citizenry is the key to avoiding another Trump, on  the left or the right.  Cheerleaders tend not to be particularly informed.  We need more independent thinkers and fewer sheep.  The sheep on the right are supporting Trump.  Who will the sheep on the left support down the road?

As a proud native Pennsylvanian, I am glad the state of Independence Hall, Gettysburg and Flight 93 is not falling for Trump's lies, despite the brutal times faced by our blue collar workers and their towns.

The Upshot states Romney won the Wilkes Barre/Scranton area by 4 points. According to the PA Dept. of State 2012 Election results website, President Obama won Lackawanna County (Scranton) by 26,753 votes. He won Luzerne County (Wilkes Barre) by 5,983 votes. This 32,735 margin offset the 31,041 advantage Mitt Romney accumulated in the 15 Counties that surround Wilkes Barre/Scranton in Northest PA. This 17 County region is far larger, (almost 584,00 total votes cast), than anyone, anywhere, would describe the WilkesBarre/Scranton area and Romney still loses! Unfortunately,Trump will do better than Romney did in this broad area but there is no way he is up 16. Trump will lose Lackawanna County, bank on it.

Thanks for this good news, Pennsylvania is fairly crucial apparently in the battle to stop that ignorant fascist from gaining power. I hope Ms. McGinty wins too, that'll help Congress start to get things done again instead of just blocking everything.

The breakdown though, once again, makes me embarrassed to be white. Seriously, white people, what's wrong with you? I get that you feel like prosperity is slipping away, but the arrogant, ignorant Trump is not going to help you at all, he never has helped people in the middle class or below. Please don't be foolhardy, and make sensible decisions this election.
That's the best news since Groundhog Day !

Please, voters, do not get complacent with projections.  This is not an election to  stay home because you assume your state is going to vote a certain way.  This election needs to be not only a loss for Trump, but also a resounding repudiation of the way his words and actions have contaminated American life for 16+ months.

Why wouldn't the White Working Class voters not trust Hillary Clinton to be on their side?

True, major corporations, financial institutions and the elite have made the Clintons rich, and a we saw from the latest from Wikileaks, they were even greedier than we imagined. But, hey, it's almost time for Santa, so maybe there will be a miracle, and Hillary Clinton would do the working-class-white's bidding instead of her donors.

Thank God for Donald Trump!  Virtually any other Republican candidate would be beating her.  I am saddened that someone with true Democratic values, such as Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren could not be nominated because of manipulations by the DNC.

Let us hope it increases beyond comprehension! The WORLD (and especially the United States of America) does not NEED a DRUMPT. He has not only
affected (wanting to destroy) our political system, he has affected his own "investments". Who will ever pay heftily to have his name on their buildings? He is a complete and utter disaster!!

I wouldn't bet a nickel on This thing.  Wikileaks is going to release something every day and they keep getting worse.  If Trump stays away from talking nonsense, who knows where we will be on Nov 8th. She has my vote but I have had it with the Clintons.  "Power" got to them and the hackers, whoever they are, are making them pay for it.  There are only two reasons I'm voting for Hillary: The make up of Supreme Court.  And she is running against a disgusting human being.

Nothing's guaranteed till November 9th. Please please please don't go getting complacent on this. Your actual vote is what counts, and it's the only thing that counts.

We've all seen a gleeful Truman with the banner headline, Dewey Defeats Truman. A 2016 version would be a nightmare come true.
Come on, PA - give us another Democratic Senator, too, please!!  So that we can put the Supreme Court  back to work.

Perhaps the NYT is treating it too gingerly, or it doesn't know quite what to make of it, but the lack of African-American voter support for Trump is a story that needs more attention. If anything tells us more about the monumental failure of the GOP to provide an inclusive platform and, indeed, a believable platform for people of color then I don't know what it is.

This resounding rejection of Donald J. Trump should wake up the GOP in that African-Americans, Hispanics and the majority of Americans of any color know that his campaign appealed to the basest instincts in our society. To all those who looked beyond the color of Barack Obama's skin just know that many in the Republican Party, all their protests to the contrary, never did so. You reap what you sow.

If you subscribed to Trump's dog whistles, and his more overt racism as well, how ironic will it be for you that Pennsylvania African-Americans defeated his "Make America White Again" appeal? I know that not all of you have such leanings but you have to own your candidate and what he stands for.
Amazing. Guess the wealthy suburbanites are going for HRC. Understandable as Trump is not on their side, but neither are Bernie and Elizabeth. They will live to regret it.

Contrary to some comments, the election is NOT OVER until every last person has voted. It's not done until even every "likely voter" in each state that has long been in the Clinton camp has voted. That is what Michelle Obama emphasized today. Elections are decided on a razor's edge, she said, sometimes a couple of votes per precinct. We need not just the White House, but the Congress and state houses. Each vote for Hillary has to be cast and so forth down the ticket because each vote is a moral statement that contributes to a mandate. Because an election is no mere contest; it's a prelude to governing.

I see hundreds of signs and bumper stickers that read..."I'm With Her."  Then again, I live in San Francisco, the Sodom and Gomorrah of the country according to Trump and his minions.  I grew up in Brooklyn, NY and moved to San Francisco in 1980.  I can not imagine living in a red state.  California is poised to become a totally democratic state with this election.  Now, I realize that there can be issues with this, when one party dominates.  However, the majority of Californians share the same values; an attempt to create a egalitarian society, to keep our citizens safe, promote equality under the law, and the opportunity to get an education and become a productive citizen.  Yes, we have our issues and I'm not painting a utopia, however, I am proud to live in a state that continues to lead the country a number of important issues.

We went to hear Clinton and Kaine speak in Philadelphia, along with some of the local candidates.
I went along with a group of climate activists and we were pleased to hear Josh Shapiro talk about environmental issues and being tough on the fracking industry to safeguard the water for the people of Pennsylvania.
There was a lot of energy there and it would be good to see it settle this election in favour of sanity and decency at last. Even more importantly I hope that the people of Pennsylvania elect Josh Shapiro as attorney general and Katy McGinty as Senator as well.

A native New Yorker, I moved to Pennsylvania about 25 years ago. Initially I lived in Erie, in the Northwestern part of the state. It was a heavily Catholic, conservative, Democratic, blue collar area at the time, which repeatedly sent Republican Tom Ridge, a native son, to Congress and then to the Governor's Mansion in Harrisburg. I now live in what is considered the South Central area of the state, a hot bed of hatred, bigotry and intolerance, populated by people helplessly watching as their communities are overrun by non-whites (the city's school district is more than 80 percent non-white) and what was once a manufacturing culture turns to one largely powered by the healthcare industry. The landscape is littered with Trump signs, as well as those screaming "Hillary Belongs in Jail," as they continue a long-standing tradition of voting against their self-interests. They are ripe for the hatred and intolerance spread by Trump, and the fears he exploits. Many of them are also the "poorly educated" Trump has said he "loves." Thank God for the cities of Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, as well as the suburban areas which surround them populated by the college educated white voters, the black voters and the women who are largely responsible for Clinton's lead in the state. As Trump and his Breitbart cohorts try every dirty trick and lie in the book to steal the election, it is those voters who are poised to give Clinton the state. May God bless them!

Clinton doesn't even need to win Ohio at this point to lock up this race. Thank god because Ohio seems to be slipping into Trumpian madness. A Times article earlier this week even hinted that Clinton could very well lock up Florida by end of next week based on early and absentee voting. Hopefully we can all sleep easy in a couple weeks
Come come on PA - let's make this a landslide for Hillary.

replies.commentBody: If the Dems retake the senate, the lame duck GOP senate will rush through a confirmation of moderate Merrick Garland rather than risk a more liberal Clinton appointee.

comments.commentBody: Maybe we'll get that 9th Supreme Court Justice after all.
